scenario:
Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella stated that the company is no longer supply constrained for Nvidia chips, citing improved chip supply for the first half of 2025 and better prospects for 2026. This could negatively impact Nvidia's stock, which has been a big winner in the AI space. Microsoft's Azure cloud growth, particularly for AI workloads, has been constrained by supply issues. The company's in-house-designed Maia accelerators may be ramping up to higher volumes in mid-2025, alleviating chip constraints. Microsoft's power constraints, rather than chip supply constraints, may be the issue, indicating continued demand for AI. 

The AI revolution is expected to drive unprecedented demand for electricity, with renewables and nuclear power not being able to meet the demand quickly. Natural gas is seen as a potential solution to meet the power needs of AI data centers. Famous hedge fund manager David Tepper and Morgan Stanley energy analyst Stephen Byrd have expressed optimism about the prospects of natural gas stocks. EQT Corporation, a natural gas play, has amassed the largest acreage in the Marcellus and Utica shale formations and has lowered its break-even costs through an acquisition. EQT's break-even price is now around $2 per MMBtu, and the company expects to hedge less after 2025, allowing it to realize higher prices if natural gas prices surge. EQT is trading at 18 times 2025 earnings expectations and could be one of the biggest winners in the year ahead, potentially even bigger than Nvidia.
